h1.span: 5th Grade Students at BDQ Enjoy Sound to Sea Prior to School Closure

p.img: Sound to Sea is a residential environmental education program on the Outer Banks. It is located at the Trinity Center in Salter Path, North Carolina. In early March, fifth-grade students from Ben D. Quinn Elementary were immersed in a habitat-based program which included multi-disciplinary hands-on activities, a challenge course, and special evening programs. Sound to Sea benefits the school group academically and socially, both at the campus and back at school.

div.p: On this wonderful three-day, two-night field trip, our students learned so many things, from the sound (marsh) to the sea (beach). Students learned about a variety of ecosystems that fall in between these locations, which include the Maritime forest, a pond ecosystem, the marsh, the beach, and the ocean. This year we even used all of these ecosystems to teach the students a valuable history lesson about the Underground Railroad. We walked through the trails from the marsh through the maritime forest, learning about the struggles that slaves endured while trying to get to a place where they would have freedom.

While visiting the maritime forest, students practiced team-building strategies along a challenge course and learned that they can depend on their teammates to help them accomplish many tasks. They met a corn snake that lives on-site and a rehabilitated red-tailed hawk that resides at the center. They learned about a pond ecosystem by visiting a pond that is on the property. They met a very friendly turtle that lives in the pond room - he loves to walk around the room and meet each of the students. The students put on waders and went into the Sound, catching a variety of organisms that call the marsh home. The instructors told the students all about their finds and then each was returned safely back to nature. Shannon, one of the students, said, “Sound to Sea was a great adventure because we got to see many creatures and wade into the sound.” Although we did not allow the students to go into the ocean, we did walk from the sound to the ocean through a tunnel that goes under the main road. On the beachside, students learned about the different sea turtles that come to our beaches and lay their eggs. They learned about the many hazards that sea turtles face in their ocean environment. They even got to try to rescue a sea turtle (stuffed animal) that had been tangled in fishing wire, using oven mitts on their hands to simulate sea turtle fins. They also went onto the beach to wiggle their way on the sand to see what it is like to be a turtle trying to move on the sand. The Sound to Sea program has acquired several shells from deceased sea turtles so that students can see how big they can become. One of the shells is close to 5 feet in diameter. Students also learned about another sea creature, the squid. The students participated in a squid dissection in one of their classes. Some of the students said that this was their favorite part, while others only wanted to watch from a distance.

Two of the main lessons at Sound to Sea are how to be a good team player and how to conserve our resources. Both of these lessons are practiced at each meal. The students each took a turn being the waitron. A waitron has to go to the dining hall early and set up the table for their group, as students eat family style. When a serving dish is empty, the waitron must go and get a refill for the whole group. This can be a very challenging lesson for some students as they don’t get to have a very peaceful meal. At each meal, the waste from the tables is calculated, and the students quickly realize how important it is to only take what you are going to eat. As we progressed through the days and meals, the waste became less and less. The instructors did say that it was important to try new things but that it was also important to take just a little to try at first because you can always get more. As time progressed, the instructors also taught the students about having a compost pile and how that can help repurpose some of the waste.

On this field trip, we learn more and more about our students. We were able to see them in a whole new way, away from the school setting, in a more relaxed real-life setting. It takes teaching to a whole new level. One of our parent chaperones, Sara Oglesby said, “This was the second time I had been to Sound to Sea with BDQ and it was just as amazing the second time around. It was wonderful watching the students learn new things, and the hands-on experience was top-notch.”
